text: As mentioned we're going to be talking about our 20 plus versions in production We're going to sort of skip over the points where we tried Istio when it was pre 1 0 because no one had a fun time with that And we never got it into production really Just quickly for those who don't know who Skyscanner are we're a meta search engine of flights hotels car hire and now packages as well We've got over 160 million monthly active users over 1 200 travel providers that we aggregate And that produces a lot of traffic a lot of microservices as previous talks have sort of covered I'm a principal software engineer there within our production platform organization I'm also co chair of SIG autoscaling within Kubernetes Hello I'm John I'm a senior software engineer at Skyscanner I've been at Skyscanner for about two and a half years now and I focus mainly on Istio with my day to day work So we'll quickly cover why Skyscanner decided to use a service mesh because it's entirely possible to run cloud native software without a service mesh despite what some vendors might tell you Our initial launch of Istio 1 4 is our service mesh within production upgrading all the way from Istio 1 4 to 1 24 and we're now at 1 26 and also the future So some of the benefits a lot of the challenges that we've experienced along the way as well So why use a service mesh We had the classic like ah we should use a service mesh It's the hot cloud native technology Everyone's saying oh Istio is amazing It's backed by But we sort of got a long way with our journey in containerization cloud native technologies without actually using a service mesh So we sort of felt a need to actually justify it So to sort of understand that I'll cover like the evolution of our architecture with containerized applications So we started off in AWS with one ECS cluster because we weren't sure about this Kubernetes 1 2 thing It wasn't backed by AWS which was our cloud vendor of choice So we were like ah we'll see where it goes We'll go with the technology backed by Google It seems like it's got a load of impetus And we achieved that by deploying a single ECS cluster Each service got deployed in there It had a load balancer and therefore a predictable DNS name in front of it So that allowed services to talk to other services But obviously that results in one big single point of We eventually ended up basically recreating that architecture but in Kubernetes because that's an evolution and we've obviously improved things there But in this case we have at least stopped paying AWS for quite as many load balancers because we can stick a single load balancer in front of it and we can just do using native Kubernetes technology we can just do a single service name under that cluster Obviously that eventually starts hitting scale problems particularly the versions of Kubernetes we're running So we're like okay let's just split it into two Kubernetes clusters That's an improvement Oh wait now everyone needs to know where their dependencies live So now if I'm talking from service A to service B I need to know that service B lives in cluster 2 not in cluster 1 I'm using that as part of the addressing Also actually it's not improved our resilience because if there's a cluster 2 outage or wait cluster A service A can no longer talk to its dependencies We've not got any failover et So we decided to steal from AWS's famously resilient cellular architecture that means that a single region going down will not impact the entire world and create multiple Kubernetes clusters with an isolated account and those would all be single AZ as our fault boundary So now if cluster A2 goes down we can just route traffic away So this is the architecture we came up with to enable that So we were using NLBs We have a component that we call the default gateway John will cover that in a bit more detail some of the benefits it brings us And we decided yeah Istio's 1 point something now We can definitely run this in prod right So we sort of chose Istio 1 4 Well we started evaluating 1 3 and it was broken enough that we went no no no we'll wait for 1 4 However we did start running into some compatibility problems So Istio 1 4 we discovered did not play nice at all with our CNI choice We needed to run our own custom patch to make it work You can go and look up all of the detail and the IP tables that made this a We also had to start doing our own certificate management because that's fun We decided very quickly we didn't want to pay AWS to do certificate management for us because it turns out they charge a lot of money for that So we went ah we can write a KMS issuer for cert manager for that which we still use to this day It works fairly well And that's open source as well if anyone else wants to use it We also thanks to our friends from Monzo decided to steal the ability to make services wait for Envoy to actually be ready before sending connections because it turns out that's not a fun thing we also decided to implement some of our own technology to deal with some problems we were having So we implemented using locality weightings cluster draining So we provided the ability for us when we were rolling out a change to a cluster to drain the traffic away from a cluster make changes and then slowly introduce traffic back into it Obviously this isn't only useful for when deploying changes but also when you're say seeing problems with a critical service in that cluster you can drain that way So it's something we use very regularly to this day The multi cluster support though in 1 4 was basic maybe experimental build your own adventure to figure out what on earth that looked like GRPC support was an afterthought at best as well But we managed to work through all these we built some of that custom functionality and then we did sort of have a slight problem where we managed to leak the implementation to our users So rather than our lovingly crafted homepage allowing people to search for flights or car hire or hotels or even our lovingly crafted error page we managed to present to everyone that visited Skyscanner with our back access tag Which to be fair some people very quickly went I see you're using Istio then However that got us a long way However we ended up stuck on Istio 1 4 for a very long time Significantly longer than we were really comfortable with certainly significantly longer than our security team were comfortable with for a number of The big one however was the removal of Mixer And for those of you not familiar with Istio that was a centralized component as part of Istio that was responsible for collecting telemetry and therefore reduced a lot of complexity etc However they called it Mixer Removal Telemetry v2 More realistically for all of the users of Istio it was actually all your monitoring goes boom Carl Stoney I think is still at Autotrader but his take on it was oh wait everyone now needs to run federated Prometheus for So all users of Istio are basically having to recreate Mixer for themselves and manage it themselves Which was not a fun time So we spent a lot of time going we'd rather not solve that ourselves too much Which John will cover some of the ways we addressed that in a bit We also decided to go from Kubernetes 1 21 to 1 23 at the time that we upgraded all the way from Istio 1 4 to 1 16 which was when we were finally comfortable So it made diagnosing some problems when we performed the upgrade slightly more problematic Where we were going oh wait we've got the release notes for 12 versions of Istio plus two versions of Kubernetes to try and untangle what we've changed in the networking Suddenly see a pile of 499s where we have a custom setup with NLBs default gateways etc We eventually managed to find that this was just the new normal and it wasn't impacting travelers somehow despite looking horrible in our graphs We also had created a custom Helm chart I think between Istio 1 4 and 1 16 it had gone from Helm chart to a completely different way of deploying it back to a Helm chart So we had to try and figure out what had changed between their two entirely separate ways of creating Helm charts for deployment There was also 12 versions of So a pile of config that we had lovingly crafted over the years did not work had been deprecated had moved to major versions etc Things had been renamed so there was a lot of trying to figure out what was going on there And finally Envoy version So one of the joys of Istio obviously is it's built on top of other cloud native technologies and mostly Envoy However we built custom Envoy filters to do a pile of stuff which now we were also committed to upgrading the Envoy version Turns out those all broke as well So had to drag in other teams within Skyscanner who were responsible for maintaining that It's not all bad news though It has brought us a lot of joy Yes I get to talk about the nice bits So Guy talks you through the pain of this upgrade process But we do have some cool things in Istio these days So as Guy mentioned we have Mixer and then Telemetry v2 And what does that look like today with Istio For those that weren't in the open Telemetry chat next door previously we had Dan Where is he There he is With us at Skyscanner and we implemented a custom way of generating Istio metrics from spans which give us nice dashboards We have a single dashboard for services that they can go in and you can see all the services that are calling them What's happening within their service itself and all the dependencies that that service itself calls which we're very happy with We also to the pain of some people in this room we've built a system that allows us to outlier detect localities As Guy touched on we've implemented draining So draining requires locality weighting Locality weighting is not compatible with outlier detecting localities So by building this system that we have we are able to do that naturally So we can support weighting whilst a service can call another service in a separate cluster and it can have let's say three failures And after that it just immediately stops trying that locality It stops trying that cluster and will try another one which isn't really possible with native Istio just now How does it We have a complex system We have as Guy said we've got a Istio gateway per cluster that all our traffic routes through We then attach a network load balancer to each gateway and then we give that network load balancer an And then for a service so if service A wants to call service B they just call service B skyscanner io And then this dual service entry basically points at these NOV IPs gives it a locality and the traffic ends up going to that gateway in the other cluster And if it just receives five 503s it will just stop trying that IP and will try another IP However load balancers cost a We also have a special gift for We at Skyscanner process 60 million requests a minute or something like that across our microservices Now when we look back at the architecture that we have here we see that every single one of these requests goes through an NLB NLBs don't cost that much when you don't use that much for But at our scale we realized it was costing us a lot of money So we made it our mission last year to move to Istio multicluster And what this looks like as you can see on the graph on the right is instead of calling an NLB for same cluster traffic we just go straight to that default gateway via the cluster IP That still gives us a single IP route for a single locality And then for multicluster we do it in obviously a non standard way at Skyscanner We call an egress gateway via a single IP and that egress gateway then transits that data to a remote default gateway And the pattern stays exactly the same as it was with an NLB And we use standard Istio sidecar multicluster discovery for this So what does it give us Implementing multicluster saved 10  of our entire company wide AWS costs which is quite a lot of It also helped our scaling So when we had NLBs it would take us two minutes for a new default gateway pod to register to this NLB And that's quite a lot of time So now with multicluster it's about 20 seconds With that shorter period of time we can increase the average CPU utilization that we run for gateways like this And that means it costs us less We spend less money on What it does mean is Istio D is doing a lot more work Instead of just scraping its own cluster it's scraping every other cluster in the region And we generally run six clusters per region So I think we scaled up about five times We went from five pods to 25 pods for Istio D So that's a side effect Worth it Service impact None essentially We actually have very slightly lower latencies We managed to do this migration without any impact or any asks on service owners because we as a platform team control all the routing and they just register their service What else have we done with We have done some nice bot detection at gateway levels That saves us some money We can do it internally We have a public gateway an Istio gateway behind some AOBs and we actually deploy authorization policies and so on Bot detection at that level Instead of running at a lambda edge Again another big cost saving We have native cross region failover So for services that are compatible not even services if a request comes in to your EOS 1 region and it goes to your service and it fails it will automatically fail over to a cross region gateway in EU Central 1 or even AP North East 1 and so on We do this from Istio client to Istio server in another region so this basically gives us a global mesh with NTLS end to end all across the world We have moved some This is a smaller one We've moved some headers from our CDM and we now pull them out with a nice WASM envoy filter We were spending again a lot of money pulling these headers out of our CDN and now we can do it fully in Istio with resources with gateways that we already have and we're already paying for And GitOps is something we've been rolling out over the last couple of and Istio is fully supported with an Argo rollout It means that Argo rollout essentially selects pods canary pods stable pods and it will do that whole transition for you for a new deployment It does it all behind the scenes for you with a virtual service and destination goals Very nice Lots more We've done a lot more but this list is definitely not comprehensive Looking forward we've implemented a lot of things that we wanted to do but we have a lot more that we do want to do with Istio One of these things is anybody using Ambient Yeah Solo are using Ambient of One of the things we want to do is move to for those that aren't fully aware of the Istio architecture Every pod that you run it gets a sidecar Sidecars are heavy Service owners have to actually think about them because sometimes if they run it in a special way these sidecars will run out of memory or CPU or so So they do have to think about it and we want to abstract that away from them So what is Ambient Instead of sidecars we use Z tunnels instead a daemon set So every node runs one Z tunnel pod and with the Istio CNI it basically injects itself into your service pods and the route tables do some magic and it goes through a Z tunnel instead No more sidecars However Z tunnels are only compatible with Layer 4 So with sidecars you get Layer 7 out You can do whatever you want Authorization policies header based routing so on You can only do it with Layer 7 You cannot do this with Z tunnel So Waypoint That's another Istio concept now that if you add a waypoint to your service it will go from the Z tunnel to the waypoint and you get the same features asterisks generally the same features as you do with a sidecar And then it will still just go to a Z tunnel for your destination We want to do it It will save us money It will greatly simplify our RMS is complicated as you probably understand from what Guy and I have both talked about There is a lot of what we call sky scannerisms that aren't fully compatible with Ambient out of the So we are in the middle of that process of planning out how we're going to do that What else do we We like most companies most large companies anyway run lots of AWS accounts We run different services on these AWS accounts For example you've got data security accounts so on And they want to access things that we run in our main platform How do we do that Right now this is how we do it For each account it will get a VPC endpoint Again this is all AWS terminology Sorry not AWS VPC endpoint to our main VPCs the ones that we control where all of our microservices run And then each account will then get its own Istio gateway where we can apply all these different routing rules so on This is what we do just now It's fine but it's a lot to We have a lot of gateways We have a lot of NLBs We've got to manage all these VPC endpoints A lot of things to So we want to try and leverage Istio in some way to make a single gateway that instead of being attached at a VPC endpoint for every account we inject authorization information And then we use an Istio gateway to pull that out and see are you allowed to go where you're trying to go through this gateway Far simpler One of the things we've worked on very recently is rate limiting and what we call quality of service priority of This is very recent last couple of We have allowed services to basically identify the type of request So at Skyscanner we obviously have things like app We've got the We've got mobile website We've got batch job partners so on We are letting services now identify the type of request that they've received at the very top of the stack the top of the and they can then set that as a value And we're going to use well we do use open telemetry baggage Shout out to Dan And then the services will automatically pull this when it's available in context and send it as an outbound header And we as a platform team then leverage Istio to say you as a service owner if you receive a request from app which is important then do this with You can give it more retries You can just give it more headroom If it's something less important like a batch job or something else you can basically tell it to go away And this is our resilience method for when we have disaster scenarios scaling problems Now I can't do a presentation without mentioning AI This is just a very short one something we as a business are obviously looking into like a lot of other businesses as a kind of AI gateway implementation Right now when you see services develop their AI stuff they're using Bedrock They're using SDKs out of the box for open AI and so on And we want to again as a platform team abstract away everything we can So we also want to abstract away AI And for those who aren't fully aware of the concept of what AI gateways are you basically get an open standard endpoint And the AI gateway can help you choose models from SASE so chat GPT whatever Or it can also route to your own self hosted GPU inference models It can do failover rate limiting and your service owners don't see any of this They just say I need an AI model and the gateway will handle all of that for you Again very early days in this but something we are looking into And that's it Any questions

segments.text: As mentioned we're going to be talking about our 20 plus versions in production We're going to sort of skip over the points where we tried Istio when it was pre 1 0 because no one had a fun time with that And we never got it into production really

Just quickly for those who don't know who Skyscanner are we're a meta search engine of flights hotels car hire and now packages as well We've got over 160 million monthly active users over 1 200 travel providers that we aggregate And that produces a lot of traffic a lot of microservices as previous talks have sort of covered
I'm a principal software engineer there within our production platform organization I'm also co chair of SIG autoscaling within Kubernetes
Hello I'm John I'm a senior software engineer at Skyscanner I've been at Skyscanner for about two and a half years now and I focus mainly on Istio with my day to day work
So we'll quickly cover why Skyscanner decided to use a service mesh because it's entirely possible to run cloud native software without a service mesh despite what some vendors might tell you

Our initial launch of Istio 1 4 is our service mesh within production upgrading all the way from Istio 1 4 to 1 24 and we're now at 1 26 and also the future So some of the benefits a lot of the challenges that we've experienced along the way as well
So why use a service mesh We had the classic like ah we should use a service mesh It's the hot cloud native technology Everyone's saying oh Istio is amazing It's backed by
But we sort of got a long way with our journey in containerization cloud native technologies without actually using a service mesh So we sort of felt a need to actually justify it
So to sort of understand that I'll cover like the evolution of our architecture with containerized applications

So we started off in AWS with one ECS cluster because we weren't sure about this Kubernetes 1 2 thing It wasn't backed by AWS which was our cloud vendor of choice So we were like ah we'll see where it goes We'll go with the technology backed by Google It seems like it's got a load of impetus

And we achieved that by deploying a single ECS cluster Each service got deployed in there It had a load balancer and therefore a predictable DNS name in front of it So that allowed services to talk to other services
But obviously that results in one big single point of
We eventually ended up basically recreating that architecture but in Kubernetes because that's an evolution and we've obviously improved things there

But in this case we have at least stopped paying AWS for quite as many load balancers because we can stick a single load balancer in front of it and we can just do using native Kubernetes technology we can just do a single service name under that cluster
Obviously that eventually starts hitting scale problems particularly the versions of Kubernetes we're running
So we're like okay let's just split it into two Kubernetes clusters That's an improvement
Oh wait now everyone needs to know where their dependencies live
So now if I'm talking from service A to service B I need to know that service B lives in cluster 2 not in cluster 1
I'm using that as part of the addressing
Also actually it's not improved our resilience because if there's a cluster 2 outage or wait cluster A service A can no longer talk to its dependencies
We've not got any failover et
So we decided to steal from AWS's famously resilient cellular architecture that means that a single region going down will not impact the entire world
and create multiple Kubernetes clusters with an isolated account and those would all be single AZ as our fault boundary
So now if cluster A2 goes down we can just route traffic away
So this is the architecture we came up with to enable that
So we were using NLBs
We have a component that we call the default gateway
John will cover that in a bit more detail some of the benefits it brings us
And we decided yeah Istio's 1 point something now
We can definitely run this in prod right
So we sort of chose Istio 1 4
Well we started evaluating 1 3 and it was broken enough that we went no no no we'll wait for 1 4
However we did start running into some compatibility problems
So Istio 1 4 we discovered did not play nice at all with our CNI choice
We needed to run our own custom patch to make it work
You can go and look up all of the detail and the IP tables that made this a
We also had to start doing our own certificate management because that's fun
We decided very quickly we didn't want to pay AWS to do certificate management for us because it turns out they charge a lot of money for that
So we went ah we can write a KMS issuer for cert manager for that which we still use to this day
It works fairly well
And that's open source as well if anyone else wants to use it
We also thanks to our friends from Monzo decided to steal the ability to make services wait for Envoy to actually be ready before sending connections because it turns out that's not a fun thing
we also decided to implement some of our own technology to deal with some problems we were having
So we implemented using locality weightings cluster draining
So we provided the ability for us when we were rolling out a change to a cluster to drain the traffic away from a cluster make changes and then slowly introduce traffic back into it
Obviously this isn't only useful for when deploying changes but also when you're say seeing problems with a critical service in that cluster you can drain that way
So it's something we use very regularly to this day
The multi cluster support though in 1 4 was basic maybe experimental build your own adventure to figure out what on earth that looked like
GRPC support was an afterthought at best as well
But we managed to work through all these we built some of that custom functionality and then we did sort of have a slight problem where we managed to leak the implementation to our users

So rather than our lovingly crafted homepage allowing people to search for flights or car hire or hotels or even our lovingly crafted error page we managed to present to everyone that visited Skyscanner with our back access tag

However we ended up stuck on Istio 1 4 for a very long time
Significantly longer than we were really comfortable with certainly significantly longer than our security team were comfortable with for a number of

However they called it Mixer Removal Telemetry v2
